137.01 COMPOSITION.
   The Police Department of the City may consist of a Chief, a Deputy Chief, a
captain, lieutenants, sergeants, patrol officers, and/or probationary patrol
officers. When any member of the Department is appointed Chief or Deputy Chief
of the Department unless otherwise provided by Council by an ordinance amending
this section, the position occupied by such member prior to his or her
appointment as Chief or Deputy Chief shall remain vacant so as to allow such
member serving as Chief or Deputy Chief to revert to his or her prior rank at
the conclusion of his or her service as Chief or Deputy Chief in accordance
with the applicable provisions of these Codified Ordinances and the laws of the
State with regard to Police Civil Service. (cf. West Virginia Code §8-14-6, and
17).
(Ord. 2016-22. Passed 12-5-16.)
137.02 SALE OF ABANDONED PROPERTY.
   (a)    The City Clerk shall, every six months, sell at public auction at the
front door of the City Hall or some other place designated by him, all property
of every kind and character, abandoned and recovered by the Police Department
and to which no claim has been made by anyone entitled to the possession
thereof. None of the property described in this section shall be sold within
sixty days after it has been recovered. No separate item of property having a
value of more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00), which value shall be
determined by the City Clerk, shall be sold until the sale thereof shall have
been advertised at least ten days prior to the date of the sale as a legal
advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation in the City, such
advertisement to be published once, and such advertisement to contain a
description of the property to be sold. The City Clerk shall make a full and
complete report of all such sales and deposit the proceeds thereof into the
City Treasury and take a receipt therefor, and the proceeds are hereby
appropriated to the General Fund. The auction provision shall not apply to
United States or foreign currency or coins.
   (b)    Any property not sold as prescribed above shall be destroyed by an
officer of the Police Department, who shall be designated by the Chief of
Police.
   (c)    All property of every kind and character which is abandoned and
recovered by the Police Department shall be subject to these auction
provisions, except that the City Clerk shall not have the authority to sell
dangerous or deadly weapons or contraband.
(Ord. 79-1. Passed 2-5-79.)
137.03 POLICEMEN'S PENSION AND RELIEF FUND.
   A Policemen's Pension and Relief Fund is hereby established for the City,
and such Fund, together with the administration and maintenance thereof and
payments therefrom, shall be as provided by West Virginia Code 8-22-16 et seq.
(1967 Code §2-54)
ARTICLE 139
Reserve Police Unit
139.01   Established; purpose; control.
139.02   Selection process for Reserve Police Unit.
139.03   Training.
139.04   Duties.
139.05   Uniforms.
139.06   Rules and regulations.
139.07   No compensation authorized.
139.08   Dismissal from Unit.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Appointment of special police officers - see W. Va. Code 8-10-1
Special school zone police officers - see W. Va. Code 8-14-5
Special parking lot or building police officers - see W. Va. Code 8-14-5a
 
139.01 ESTABLISHED; PURPOSE; CONTROL.
   A Reserve Police Unit is hereby established as a private auxiliary part of
the St. Albans Police Department. The unit will be under the direction of the
Chief of Police or his designee, as officer in charge. The creation of the
Reserve Police Unit is solely for the purpose of providing limited aid and
assistance to the Police Department of the City for performing routine traffic
and crowd control and assisting in accident investigation and reports, or
similar work. Members of the Reserve Police Unit serve entirely at the will and
pleasure of the Mayor of the City subject to supervisory control and authority
of the Chief of Police who reports to the Mayor. (Ord. 2001- 05. Passed 4-16-
01.)
139.02 SELECTION PROCESS FOR RESERVE POLICE UNIT.
   Every applicant shall submit an application in the same manner as any person
applying under civil service provisions, but it is expressly provided that no
civil service position and/or rights or protection is created or applies to any
applicant or person applying or selected to serve as a member of the Reserve
Police Unit. The Chief of Police and/or the officer in charge shall cause a
background check to be conducted on each applicant. All applicants shall
possess a valid West Virginia operators license and be at least eighteen years
of age.
(Ord. 2001-05. Passed 4-16-01.)
139.03 TRAINING.
   Each member of the Reserve Police Unit is to receive training in the use of
chemical agents and all other defensive weapons used by the Police Department,
except firearms, before being utilized in a reserve police capacity. In
addition, reserve police officers shall receive training in report writing and
other needed paper work as directed by the Chief of Police or the officer in
charge. The training will be conducted by members of the St. Albans Police
Department as much as possible. At no time shall a member of a Reserve Police
Unit carry, brandish or otherwise have on his or her possession a firearm of
any type while on or reporting to or from duty. Nor are Reserve Police Unit
members authorized to use a firearm, or other deadly weapon in the exercise of
their duties and responsibilities as reserve police.
(Ord. 2001-05. Passed 4-16-01.)
139.04 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Reserve Police Unit are to assist the regular department
members with the safety and protection of the general public. Reserve police
officers may be used for traffic control, assisting with crowds, and perform
patrol duties as needed. Reserve police officers cannot effect an arrest, but
may assist a regular member of the St. Albans Police Department in the effect
of an arrest. Reserve police officers may issue parking violations, take minor
complaint reports and assist the on-duty communications clerk as needed.
(Ord. 2001-05. Passed 4-16-01.)
139.05 UNIFORMS.
   Uniforms for the Reserve Police Unit will be furnished by the City. The
uniform will be the same color as the regular duty officers. The uniform will
be worn with a breast badge, nameplate, and two patches with the lettering
“RESERVE POLICE”. A cap shall also be worn. Reserve police officers shall wear
a duty belt with a baton and chemical agent, provided they have received
training in their use. Reserve police officers shall also carry a flashlight
and a pen and notebook. When available, the Police Department may assign a
handheld radio for use while the reserve police are on duty. The uniform will
only be worn while on duty, going to and from a duty assignment and, if needed,
during training.
(Ord. 2001-05. Passed 4-16-01.)
139.06 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Reserve Police Unit shall operate under the Rules and Regulations of the
Police Department. The appointment and continuance as a reserve police officer
shall depend upon the willingness and ability to answer calls of duty, and to
respond positively and appropriately to training and compliance with orders
from the Chief of Police, or the officer in charge.
(Ord. 2001-05. Passed 4-16-01.)
139.07 NO COMPENSATION AUTHORIZED.
   No member of the reserve police shall receive and retain any compensation
for services rendered. Any compensation paid for any service shall be placed in
the General Fund for the purpose of offsetting the cost for equipment for the
reserve police.
(Ord. 2001-05. Passed 4-16-01.)
139.08 DISMISSAL FROM UNIT.
   The Chief of Police and/or the officer in charge of the reserve unit may
dismiss a member from the unit, with or without cause, at any time, or for any
reason.
(Ord. 2001-05. Passed 4-16-01.)
ARTICLE 141
Fire Department
141.01   Composition and organization.
141.02   Duties.
141.03   Chief; appointment; duties.
141.04   Chain of command; obedience to orders.
141.05   Rules and regulations.
141.06   Firemen's Pension and Relief Fund.
141.07   Emergency response fee for non-residents.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Appointments - see CHTR. Sec.
4
General provisions - see CHTR. Sec.
32
Civil service - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-15
 
141.01 COMPOSITION AND ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   The City Fire Department shall be comprised of such fire companies and
other units with such personnel who shall have such ranks and grades as shall
from time to time be authorized by Council.
   (b)   The Department shall consist of a Fire Chief, captains, lieutenants,
firemen, probationary firemen, mechanic and paid on-call firefighters. The Fire
Chief shall have the responsibility of providing for the organization of the
Department into companies and other units. The organization as prescribed by
the Fire Chief shall be subject to the approval of and amendment by the Mayor
and Council.
(Ord. 89-7. Passed 6-5-89.)
141.02 DUTIES.
   The Fire Department shall protect the residents and property within the City
and, when authorized by intergovernmental agreement or otherwise, residents and
property outside the City, from the dangers of fire and other emergencies which
may from time to time arise; shall take such preventive measures by conducting
inspections, issuing citations, providing educational and training programs and
otherwise as may be necessary, desirable and lawful to prevent the occurrence
of fires and explosions within the City; shall assist in protecting and
providing aid to residents and others within or near the City from fire and
other emergencies which threaten life including emergencies on the Coal and
Kanawha Rivers, emergencies arising from automobile accidents and other
emergencies and calamities; and shall discharge such other duties as may from
time to time be assigned to or imposed upon the Department by these Codified
Ordinances, intergovernmental and other agreements duly ratified by Council and
applicable laws, rules and regulations of the State and the United States of
America.
(Ord. 89-7. Passed 6-5-89.)
141.03 CHIEF; APPOINTMENT; DUTIES.
   (a)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall be appointed by the Mayor,
subject to the confirmation of Council, at the will and pleasure of the Mayor
or until the next Municipal election and, thereafter, until his successor is
duly appointed and qualified in the same or like manner to that by which the
Chief of Police and other Municipal officers are appointed in conformity with
Section 4 of the City Charter.
   (b)   The Chief shall be the commanding officer of the Fire Department and
shall be responsible to the Mayor and Council for the administration, training,
discipline, morale and effective deployment and utilization of the members of
the Department. He shall further be responsible for the proper supervision of
the maintenance, deployment and utilization of the property, equipment and
apparatus of the Department.
   (c)   The Fire Chief shall have all such powers as may be necessary and
lawful to fulfill the responsibilities imposed upon him by these Codified
Ordinances, including, but not limited to, the following:
      (1)   He shall be in command of the Department to include management,
assignment of duties, work hours and general supervision of every officer,
member and employee of the Department during all hours when personnel are on
duty including such times as actual emergencies and fires exist and during all
training sessions.
      (2)   He shall supervise the maintenance, upkeep, purchase of and repair
of the firehouses, trucks and all apparatus and equipment belonging to or
assigned for use by the Department.
      (3)   He shall have general supervision of the purchase, storage and
issuance of all supplies and expendable materials maintained by, for or used by
the Department.
      (4)   He shall be responsible for supervising the preparation of all
records required by the Mayor or Council and all records required by the State
or any subdivision of the State. He shall report annually to the Mayor and
Council with regard to all fires occurring since his previous report, the value
of the property lost as a result of such fires, and shall make suggestions as
to rules, regulations and procedures which in his opinion should be adopted to
reduce the number of fires, the loss of property and the loss of life within
the City.
         (Ord. 89-7. Passed 6-5-89.)
141.04 CHAIN OF COMMAND; OBEDIENCE TO ORDERS.
   The chain of command within the Fire Department shall run from the Fire
Chief to the officers and firemen within the Department down in a descending
course in order of rank and seniority within rank. Subordinates shall have the
powers and shall perform the duties of their immediate supervisor when such
supervisor is absent or disabled. Each member of the Department shall obey all
lawful orders of his superior in the chain of command and any disobedience to
or failure to comply with any lawful order shall subject the disobedient member
to such disciplinary action and penalty as may be prescribed and authorized by
the rules and regulations of the Department.
(Ord. 89-7. Passed 6-5-89.)
 
141.05 RULES AND REGULATIONS
   The Fire Chief shall prepare rules and regulations for the Fire Department
which rules and regulations shall not be inconsistent with State law or other
provisions of these Codified Ordinances and which rules and regulations shall
provide for the management of the Department; personnel policies for the
members of the Department; and for disciplinary procedures which procedures
shall not be inconsistent with applicable civil service laws or ordinances of
the State or the City. Prior to becoming effective, such rules and regulations
shall be ratified, confirmed and approved by a resolution of Council. Such
rules and regulations may from time to time be amended by the Fire Chief but in
the case of an amendment, such amendment shall not be effective until ratified,
confirmed and approved by a resolution of Council.
(Ord. 89-7. Passed 6-5-89.)
 
141.06 FIREMEN'S PENSION AND RELIEF FUND.
   The Firemen's Pension and Relief Fund, as established by a prior ordinance
adopted by Council, is hereby continued without interruption. Such Fund,
together with the administration and maintenance thereof and payments
therefrom, shall continue to be as provided by West Virginia Code 8-22-16 et
seq, as now in effect or as may be from time to time be hereafter amended.
(Ord. 89-7. Passed 6-5-89.)
 
141.07 EMERGENCY RESPONSE FEE FOR NON-RESIDENTS.
   (a)   Response to Motor Vehicle Emergencies. In the event it is necessary
for the Fire Department to respond to extinguish a fire or abate any other type
of emergency, on or about any motor vehicle owned by a non-resident of the City
of St. Albans, or any business entity not assessed a Unified City Service Fee
under Section
954.01 of the St. Albans City Codified Ordinances, a fee of two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) shall be assessed upon the owner of such vehicle. There shall
be an additional fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) assessed upon such owner
for each Fire Department apparatus remaining on the scene of the emergency
after the first initial hour of emergency service. Said owner shall also be
liable for, and the City shall reserve the right to recover from such owner,
the cost and expense for the utilization of any specialized or disposable
equipment or materials necessary to render an emergency scene safe and secure.
 
   (b)   Response to Emergencies Outside St. Albans Corporate Limits. In the
event it is necessary for the Fire Department to respond outside the corporate
City limits due to the inability or failure of the responsible Fire Department
in that fire district to respond, the property owner shall be assessed two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Such owner of property requiring emergency
service shall be liable for the cost and expense for the utilization of any
specialized or disposable equipment or material necessary to render an
emergency scene safe and secure. This will not be applicable when the St.
Albans Fire Department is responding to a request for assistance consistent
with approved mutual aid agreements.
 
   (c)   Specialized Emergency Service, Including But Not Limited to Water
Rescue, Trench Rescue, High Angle Rescue or Hazardous Material Incidents. In
the event it is necessary for the Fire Department to respond to any emergency
including but not limited to Water Rescue and Recovery, Trench Rescue, High
Angle Rescue or Hazardous Material incidents either inside or outside the
corporate limits of the City of St. Albans, such owner or responsible party
shall be subject to a fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the
initial hour and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each additional hour
thereafter that the Fire Department remains on scene. Such owner or responsible
party requiring emergency service shall be liable for the cost and expense for
the utilization of any specialized or disposable equipment or material
necessary to render an emergency scene safe and secure. An additional fee of
twenty dollars ($20.00) per person, per hour shall be assessed to the owner or
responsible party. (Ord. 2002-12. Passed 6-3-02.)
 
ARTICLE 143
Director of Public Works
143.01   Creation.
143.02   Duties.
143.03   Minimum training and experience.
143.04   Powers and authority.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Street and sidewalk areas - see S.U. & P.S. Chap. One
Solid waste collection - see S.U. & P.S. Art.
953
 
143.01 CREATION.
   Under the authority granted to the City under Chapter 8 of the West Virginia
Code, the office of Director of Public Works is hereby created.
(Ord. 2004-29. Passed 9-20-04.)
143.02 DUTIES.
   Under direction and oversight of the Public Works Committee, the position of
Director of Public Works or his designee, shall carry out the essential public
service of collecting, removing, and disposing of refuse produced in the
households and places of business within the City, and, shall have
responsibility of maintaining and repairing the streets, alleys, sidewalks and
other public ways, storm water drains and other like improvements of the City
and other such duties as are specified by the Codified Ordinances. Employees in
this classification perform supervisory and technical work. This position is
responsible for supervising and directing all assigned employees within the
department.
(Ord. 2004-29. Passed 9-20-04.)
143.03 MINIMUM TRAINING AND EXPERIENCE.
   The Director of Public Works shall have a Bachelor’s degree in public
administration, or closely related field supplemented by years previous
experience and/or training that includes supervision. In lieu of the above
degree requirements, the Director may substitute an equivalent combination of
education, training or experience.
(Ord. 2004-29. Passed 9-20-04.)
143.04 POWERS AND AUTHORITY.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Department of Public Works which shall
be under the administrative and operational control of the Director.
   (b)   The Director is authorized to enforce all the provisions of this and
other related ordinances adopted and made a part of the Codified Ordinances.
   (c)   The Director shall have the power to render written and oral
interpretations of this Code and to adopt and enforce administrative procedures
in order to clarify the application of its provisions. Such interpretations,
rules and regulations shall be in conformance with the intent and purpose of
the relevant articles of the Codified Ordinances.
   (d)   The Director may request, and shall receive, the assistance and
cooperation of other officials of the City so far as is required in the
discharge of the duties required by this Code or other pertinent law or
ordinance.
(Ord. 2004-29. Passed 9-20-04.)
ARTICLE 147
Boards and Commissions Generally
147.01   Continued absence from meetings.
147.02   City residency.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Removal of officers and employees - see CHTR. Sec.
9
 
147.01 CONTINUED ABSENCE FROM MEETINGS.
   Any member of a committee, board or commission who is absent from three
consecutive meetings of such committee, board or commission, unless such
absence is due to an injury or illness, may be replaced by the appointment of
another member to such committee, board or commission and notice of such
appointment shall be given in writing to the chairman of such committee, board
or commission.
(1967 Code Sec. 2-1)
147.02 CITY RESIDENCY.
   Any member of a committee, board or commission who for any reason ceases to
be a resident of the City of St. Albans will be replaced by the appointment of
another member to such committee, board or commission and notice of such
appointment shall be given in writing to the chairman of such committee, board
or commission.
   This section shall be advertised in accordance with the applicable
provisions of the Charter and Codified Ordinances of the City of St. Albans,
West Virginia.
(Ord. 96-08. Passed 5-6-96.)
ARTICLE 149
Parks and Recreation
PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT
149.01    Definitions.
149.02    Declaration of public policy; purpose of article.

149.05    Duties and powers of the City Parks and Recreation Superintendent.
149.06    Construction and acquisition of recreational property.
149.07    Budget and expenses.
149.08    Rules and regulations.
PARKS AND RECREATION COMMITTEE
149.09    Created; members; compensation.
149.10    Purpose of committee; consultation.
149.11    Officers; rules; meetings; records.
149.12    Duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Park Board - see CHTR. §
36
Public recreation and playgrounds - see W. Va. Code Art. 10-2
Absence of members from meetings - see ADM.
147.01
Liquor on public grounds - see GEN. OFF. 521.04
 
PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT
 
149.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
   (a)    "Department" means the St. Albans Parks and Recreation Department.
      (Ord. 82-19. Passed 6-22-82.)
   (b)    "Manager" means the Manager of the City appointed pursuant to the
provisions of Article
132. (Ord. 86-14. Passed 8-4-86.)
149.02 DECLARATION OF PUBLIC POLICY; PURPOSE OF ARTICLE.
   It is hereby declared to be the public policy of the City and the purpose of
this article to promote the public health, safety and welfare by creating a
Parks and Recreation Department, relating to the control, regulation,
maintenance and operation of all recreational facilities in areas within the
City that have been entrusted to it by Council.
(Ord. 82-19. Passed 6-22-82.)
149.03 DEPARTMENT CREATED.
   There is hereby created a Parks and Recreation Department.
(Ord. 82-19. Passed 6-22-82.)
149.04 CITY PARKS AND RECREATION SUPERINTENDENT; OTHER PERSONNEL.
   The head of the Department of Parks and Recreation shall be the City Parks
and Recreation Superintendent, who shall be appointed by the Mayor and
confirmed by Council to serve at the will and pleasure of the Mayor. The City
Parks and Recreation Superintendent shall report to and be subject to the
supervision of the Manager. The Manager shall appoint, within the limits of
funds available for such purpose, other supporting personnel as may be
necessary to carry out the duties of his office. All such personnel shall
perform their respective duties under the general supervision of the Manager
and the specific direction of the City Parks and Recreation Superintendent.
(Ord. 86-14. Passed 8-4-86.)
149.05 DUTIES AND POWERS OF THE CITY PARKS AND RECREATION SUPERINTENDENT.
   The City Parks and Recreation Superintendent shall administer and enforce
the provisions of this article. Every power granted or duty imposed upon the
City Parks and Recreation Superintendent under this article may be exercised
and performed in the name of the Superintendent or the Manager by any employee,
subject to such conditions and limitations as the City Parks and Recreation
Superintendent or the Manager may prescribe.
   The Manager shall have the power and authority to establish, equip, maintain
and operate recreational parks, playgrounds and other recreational facilities
for public uses. The Manager or the City Parks and Recreation Superintendent
shall, however, consult with the Parks and Recreation Committee prior to taking
such action.
   The City Parks and Recreation Superintendent shall attend the meetings of
the Parks and Recreation Committee and afford technical assistance to that
Committee.
(Ord. 86-14. Passed 8-4-86.)
149.06 CONSTRUCTION AND ACQUISITION OF RECREATIONAL PROPERTY.
   Council may establish, construct, acquire and set aside for recreational
parks, playgrounds and other recreational facilities any real or personal
property heretofore or hereafter acquired by the City. Such property shall be
under the management of the Manager when turned over to the Manager by Council
for such purposes.
(Ord. 86-14. Passed 8-4-86.)
149.07 BUDGET AND EXPENSES.
   The Manager shall submit to the Mayor and Council a budget for each fiscal
year for recreation and parks as a part of the budget of the Manager. Council
shall thereupon consider such budget and make such allowances to the Manager
for parks and recreation as it shall deem proper. All net revenues received
from the use and operation of any facility operated by the Manager for
recreational or park purposes shall be paid to the City Treasurer's General
Fund. All expenditures made by the Department shall be accounted for to the
City Treasurer and, where required by ordinances of the City or the City
Treasurer, shall be handled, vouchered and requisitioned for and in the same
manner as the other General Fund expenditures.
(Ord. 86-14. Passed 8-4-86.)
149.08 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The City Parks and Recreation Superintendent may promulgate such rules and
regulations as he may, acting with the advice and consent of the Parks and
Recreation Committee, from time to time, deem appropriate. A copy of such rules
and regulations and any amendments thereto shall be filed in the office of the
City Clerk prior to their effective date.
(Ord. 86-14. Passed 8-4-86.)
PARKS AND RECREATION COMMITTEE
149.09 CREATED; MEMBERS; COMPENSATION.
   There is hereby created a Parks and Recreation Committee, the membership of
which shall consist of nine persons. At least one of the members of such
Committee, but no more than three shall be members of Council. If more than one
Council member is appointed, the Mayor shall designate which Council member
will be responsible for reporting Committee activities to Council. Council
members shall serve until the end of their terms. All members shall be
residents of the City and shall be appointed by the Mayor. No more than two
non-Council members of the Committee shall reside in the same ward of the City.
All members appointed by the Mayor shall be confirmed by Council.
   The Mayor shall appoint the members of the Committee created by this section
as soon as possible after the adoption of this section, such appointees to
serve, two for a term of three years, two for a term of two years and two for a
term of one year. Thereafter, on or before July 1 of each year, there shall be
appointed members to replace those members whose terms have expired who shall
serve for a term of three years from July 1, in the year of their appointment
and until their respective successors have been appointed and qualified. All
vacancies, other than by reason of expiration of term of office, shall be
filled in the same manner as original appointments are made and shall be for
the unexpired terms only.
   The City Parks and Recreation Director shall be an ex-officio member of the
Committee.
   Members of the Committee shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 9-2-97.)
149.10 PURPOSE OF COMMITTEE; CONSULTATION.
   The purpose of the Parks and Recreation Committee shall be to make careful
and comprehensive surveys and studies of present parks and playgrounds, along
with a study of the future growth of the City, with the general purpose of
advising the Mayor and Council of ways to accomplish a coordinated, adjusted
and harmonious development of a system of parks and playgrounds and other
recreational areas which will, in accordance with present and future needs,
best and most efficiently and economically promote the health, safety, morals,
order, convenience and general welfare of the residents, including among other
things, the location of parks, playgrounds and other recreational areas
conveniently distributed as to population. In preparing these studies the Parks
and Recreation Committee shall consult and cooperate with the Planning
Commission. (Ord. 82-19. Passed 6-22-82.)
149.11 OFFICERS; RULES; MEETINGS; RECORDS.
   The Mayor shall, at his discretion, appoint a chairman of the Parks and
Recreation Committee. The Parks and Recreation secretary shall serve as
secretary to the Committee. The Parks and Recreation Committee shall adopt such
rules as may be necessary for the transaction of its business, hold monthly
meetings open to the public and shall keep a record of its official proceedings
which shall be open to the public. The secretary of the Committee shall
maintain written minutes of all Committee meetings accurately reflecting the
business transacted and shall file a copy of the same with the City Clerk. A
quorum of the Committee shall be required at all meetings during which business
is conducted. Five members of the Committee shall constitute a quorum.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 9-2-97.)
149.12 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Parks and Recreation Committee shall be to advise the
Mayor and the Council of recommendations for the development of parks,
playgrounds and other recreational areas within the jurisdiction of the City,
which, in the opinion of the Committee, bear relation to planning, welfare and
growth of the City and to make recommendations as to their use and the fees
thereby charged for their use.
   The Parks and Recreation Committee shall on an annual basis, if needed,
recommend any changes to the previously approved by resolution rate schedule
for reasonable rates, fees and charges for the use of the municipal pool,
contiguous property and other properties as managed by the Parks and Recreation
Committee, which fees shall be collected by the Clerk-Treasurer of the City or
the Clerk-Treasurer’s designee. Council, thereafter, shall adopt or amend such
recommended rates, fees and charges by resolution.
(Ord. 2019-07. Passed 6-3-19.)
ARTICLE 151
Planning Commission
151.01   Creation.
151.02   Purpose.
151.03   Composition and membership; vacancies.
151.04   Original appointments.
151.05   Officers.
151.06   Offices, facilities and expenses.
151.07   Meetings; quorum.
151.08   Powers and duties.
151.09   Chapter 8A of West Virginia Code adopted.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see W. Va. Code 8A-2-1
Composition; organization - see W. Va. Code 8A-2-3
Powers and duties - see W. Va. Code 8A-2-11
Preparation of comprehensive plan - see W. Va. Code 8A-3-3
Approval of subdivision plats - see W. Va. Code 8A-5-8
Hearings of zoning amendments - see W. Va. Code 8A-7-9
Continued absence of members from meetings - see ADM.
147.01
 
151.01 CREATION.
   There is hereby created and established a Municipal Planning Commission for
the City. (1967 Code §2-39)
151.02 PURPOSE.   
   It is the object of this article to improve the present health, safety,
convenience, and welfare of the residents of the City and to plan for the
future development of the City to the end that highway systems be carefully
planned, that new community centers grow only with adequate highway, utility,
health, educational and recreational facilities, that the needs of industry and
business be recognized in future growth, that residential areas provide healthy
surroundings for family life, and that the growth of the community is
commensurate with and promotive of the efficient and economical use of public
funds.
(1967 Code §2-40)
151.03 COMPOSITION AND MEMBERSHIP; VACANCIES.
   (a)   The Planning Commission of the City shall consist of seven members,
all of whom shall be residents of the City, who shall be qualified by knowledge
and experience in matters pertaining to the development of the City and who
shall include representatives of business, industry and labor. Three-fifths of
all members shall have been residents of the Municipality for at least ten
years prior to nomination.
   (b)   One member of the Municipal Planning Commission shall also be a member
of Council, and one member shall also be a member of the administrative
department of the City. The term of these two members shall be coextensive with
the term of office to which he has been elected or appointed, unless the Mayor
and Council, at the first regular meeting of each year, appoint others to serve
as the City’s representatives. The remaining five members shall be appointed
for terms of three years each, except those members first appointed as provided
in Section
151.04. They shall be nominated by the Mayor and confirmed by Council.
   (c)   Vacancies shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term only.
(1967 Code §2-41)
151.04 ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS.
   For the original appointment of the five members of the Municipal Planning
Commission provided for in Section
151.03, two members shall be appointed for one year, two members for two years
and one member for three years.
(1967 Code §2-42)
151.05 OFFICERS.
   At its first regular meeting in each year, the Municipal Planning Commission
shall elect from its members a president and vice-president. It shall designate
a member of the Commission to act as an advisory member of the County Planning
Commission and it may appoint a secretary. (1967 Code §2-43)
151.06 OFFICES, FACILITIES AND EXPENSES.
   Council shall provide the Municipal Planning Commission with suitable
offices and facilities and shall provide by appropriation a sum sufficient to
defray the reasonable expenses of the Commission to enable it to carry out its
duties.
(1967 Code §2-44)
151.07 MEETINGS; QUORUM.
   The Municipal Planning Commission shall fix the time for holding regular
meetings, but it shall meet at least once in the months of January, April, July
and October.
   The provisions of West Virginia Code 8-24-8 et seq. shall govern special
meetings and quorums. (1967 Code §2-45)
151.08 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Municipal Planning Commission shall have all powers and perform all
duties provided for in West Virginia Code Article 8-24 and such provisions are
incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference. (1967 Code §2-46)
151.09 CHAPTER 8A OF WEST VIRGINIA CODE ADOPTED.
   There is included, and incorporated, by reference, into Article 151, of the
Official Code of the City of St. Albans, West Virginia provisions of Chapter 8A
of the West Virginia Code, as amended, which pertain to the subject matter of
Article 151 of the City Code, as and when the provisions of Chapter 8A of the
West Virginia Code pertain, where reference is made in Article 151 of the City
Code to provisions of former West Virginia Code Chapter 8, Article 24.
   Further, all provisions of the Official Code of the City of St. Albans, West
Virginia which refer to provisions of the former Chapter 8, Article 24 of the
West Virginia Code are repealed to the extent the same are contrary to the
provisions of Chapter 8A of the West Virginia Code. (Ord. 2006-16. Passed 9-18-
06.)
ARTICLE 153
Municipal Utility Commission
153.01   Created; composition; chairman.
153.02   Compensation; members reimbursed for expenses.
153.03   Powers and duties.
153.04   Annual budget.
153.05   Approval of budget.
153.06   Transfer of funds.
153.07   Right of eminent domain to acquire land.
153.08   Signatures on checks.
153.09   Administrative and/or supervisory compensation.
153.10   General manager; co-managers.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Municipal waterworks systems - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-19
Combined waterworks and sewerage systems - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-20
Sewage works and sanitary districts - see W. Va. Code Art. 16-13
Continued absence of member from meetings - see ADM.
147.01
 
153.01 CREATED; COMPOSITION; CHAIRMAN.
   The Municipal Utility Commission, hereinafter referred to as the Commission,
shall consist of the Mayor and four members to be appointed by the Mayor and
approved by City Council. The Commission members shall include two qualified
voters of the City and two members of City Council, all of whom shall have
voting authority. Any proposed appointment to the Commission shall be disclosed
to City Council at least one meeting prior to the appointment being voted upon
by City Council. Those members of City Council nominated to serve on the
Commission shall recuse themselves from voting on their approval by City
Council. Appointed Council Members shall serve a term of four years or the
duration of the current term of City Council if less than four years. One
qualified voter shall be appointed for a term of three years and one for a term
of five years. Members may be reappointed. The Mayor shall act as chairman of
the combined utility and in the Mayor’s absence, the vice Mayor shall fulfill
such obligation. As chairman, the Mayor shall act as the chief executive
officer of the combined utility and shall from time to time recommend to the
Commission such measures as he may deem needful for the welfare of the combined
utility. He shall be responsible for the daily management of finances,
personnel and operations subject to the direction and approval of the
Commission.
(Ord. 2005-20. Passed 10-17-05.)
153.02 COMPENSATION; MEMBERS REIMBURSED FOR EXPENSES.
   Members of the Commission, other than the Mayor, shall be compensated at the
rate of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per attendance at regular
monthly meetings, total compensation per member not to exceed four thousand,
eight hundred dollars ($4,800.00) per annum. Each member of the Commission
shall be entitled to payment for reasonable expenses incurred in the
performance of his or her duties.
(Ord. 2020-06. Passed 4-20-20.)
153.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The control, operation and maintenance of the waterworks system owned by the
City, located within the City and the adjoining territory, including filtration
and treatment plant and facilities, intake pipes, mains, distribution system,
reservoirs, meters, office equipment, accounts receivable and such waterworks
system complete in every detail and aspect, and the sewerage system as a
complete and entire sewerage system located within the City, and the sewers in
the adjoining territory outside the City connected to and served by the
sewerage system of the City is hereby vested in the Municipal Utility
Commission for the purposes stated in this article. Such Commission shall
provide for the efficient operation of such waterworks and sewerage system and
shall have the authority to provide for the construction, extension,
acquisition, improvement, equipment, custody, operation, maintenance,
administration and collection of revenues, including the collection of the
charges for the use of the sewers and the water rates and charges as now or
hereafter provided for by ordinance of Council, and such Commission shall have
the authority to employ engineers, architects, managers, inspectors,
superintendents, collectors, attorneys and other employees and do all other
things necessary or incidental thereto. Such Commission shall have the
authority, in its own name, to enter into contracts, to sue and be sued.
(1967 Code Sec. 2-49)
153.04 ANNUAL BUDGET.
   On or before May 1 of each year the Commission shall submit a written
itemized annual budget to the City Council including estimated revenues and
estimated expenditures for the next fiscal year, itemized by purposes and
objects, including but not limited to the number, classification and
compensation of all persons employed and the amount to be paid to such
employees according to classification including any contract employees. This
written request shall include a capital expenditure budget and be on an
accounting basis in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles
which will reflect all revenue earned and all expenses incurred. The budget
request shall also show the amount needed to retire bonds, deposits to be made
to special funds, including sinking funds, capital improvements funds, customer
installations, maintenance and repair, and such other items as necessary to
show a detailed statement of the expenditure of all funds.
(Ord. 2005-20. Passed 10-17-05.)
153.05 APPROVAL OF BUDGET.
   The City Council shall examine the budget as scheduled pursuant to the
provisions of the preceding section and if it finds that it conforms to the
requirements of this chapter and is in accordance with sound fiscal policy, it
shall approve the budget. The City Council shall have the authority to reduce
any and all items of the budget submitted. The expenditure of money shall only
be made in accordance with the budget line items as approved unless the budget
is amended with the consent and prior written approval of the City Council.
Those members of City Council serving on the Commission shall recuse themselves
from voting on the approval of the budget by City Council.
(Ord. 2005-20. Passed 10-17-05.)
153.06 TRANSFER OF FUNDS.
   The City Council may, upon written request from the Commission or the Mayor,
or for good cause shown, authorize the transfer of amounts between items of the
total appropriations or between funds or accounts. Those members of City
Council serving on the Commission shall recuse themselves from voting on the
approval of any proposed transfer of amounts by City Council. (Ord. 2005-20.
Passed 10-17-05.)
153.07 RIGHT OF EMINENT DOMAIN TO ACQUIRE LAND.
   The Mayor, acting for and on behalf of the City, and the Commission so
acting, are each hereby authorized to exercise the right of eminent domain for
the City in the name of and on behalf of the City, in such proceedings
authorized by law, to acquire estates in land, including the fee, and easements
and right of way to be used for the construction, operation, maintenance,
repair, replacement and removal of public sanitary and storm sewer lines, water
lines, and for such other equipment and facilities proper and necessary for the
operation of a public water, sanitary sewer and storm sewer system, or either
of them, within the City.
(Ord. 2005-20. Passed 10-17-05.)
153.08 SIGNATURES ON CHECKS.
   All checks for any account of the Municipal Utility Commission shall bear
the personal signature of the Mayor or a facsimile affixed by the City official
appointed by the Mayor.
(Ord. 95-12. Passed 8-7-95.)
153.09 ADMINISTRATIVE AND/OR SUPERVISORY COMPENSATION.
   An increase in compensation for any employee exercising administrative and/
or supervisory responsibilities shall be ineffective and void without the prior
written approval of the City Council. Those members of City Council serving on
the Commission shall recuse themselves from voting on the approval of any
proposed increase by City Council.
(Ord. 2005-20. Passed 10-17-05.)
153.10 GENERAL MANAGER; CO-MANAGERS.
   The Commission may employ a general manager or co-managers upon approval of
the St. Albans City Council. The Commission shall establish job descriptions to
include detailed job duties and responsibilities as well as minimum
qualifications for the general manager and co-manager positions subject to the
approval of the City Council. Those members of City Council serving on the
Commission shall recuse themselves from voting on the approval of proposed job
descriptions by City Council. The position of general manager or co-manager(s)
shall be filled by majority vote of the Municipal Utility Commission and
subsequent approval of the City Counsel. Any vacancy shall be advertised as a
Class I Legal Advertisement. The successful candidates shall be selected from
the respondents to the advertisement following a thorough interview,
documentation of qualifications and employment history. The position(s) shall
be for a term of not less than one year and may be renewed from year to year
with the approval of the Commission with such terms and conditions as the
Commission may require. The compensation for the general manager or co-manager
(s) shall be in accordance with the approved budget and shall be subject to
approval by the City Council. Those members of City Council serving on the
Commission shall recuse themselves from voting on the approval of manager(s)
compensation by City Council.
(Ord. 2020-07. Passed 4-20-20.)

time by the governing bodies of all participating governments. (1967 Code §2-
67)
