Vaccination of dogs for rabies - see W. Va. Code Art. 19-20A
Animals and fowl generally - see GEN. OFF. Art.
505
 
507.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “Dog” means all members of the canine family of either sex and at
least six months of age, unless otherwise specified in this article.
   (b)   (1)   “Vicious dog” means:
         A.   Any dog that when unprovoked bites or attacks a human being or
other animal either on public or private property.
         B.   Any dog with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to
attack unprovoked, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of human
beings or domestic animals.
         C.   Any dog which attacks a human being or domestic animal without
provocation.
         D.   Any dog owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of
dog fighting or any dog trained for dog fighting.
      (2)   “Vicious dog” does not include either of the following:
         A.   A dog that has killed or caused serious injury or has attacked or
injured any person while that person was committing or attempting to commit a
criminal offense;
         B.   A police dog while being used to assist one or more law
enforcement officers in the performance of their official duties.
            (Ord. 2003-25. Passed 11-3-03.)
507.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Every person owning, maintaining or harboring a dog in the City shall obtain
a license for such dog in accordance with the provisions of this article.
(1967 Code §3-8)
507.03 APPLICATION; ISSUANCE; TAG; CERTIFICATE;
   Every person owning, maintaining or harboring a dog in the City shall apply
to the City Clerk for a license for each dog so owned, maintained or harbored,
and such application shall show whether such dog is a male or female.
   After the payment of the fee set forth in Section
507.04, the City Clerk shall issue to such person a license together with an
official tag, which tag shall be fastened to the collar of the dog so licensed;
provided, however, that before issuing such license tag there shall be
exhibited to the City Clerk a certificate from a registered professional
veterinarian to the effect that the dog for which a license is applied has been
duly and properly inoculated for rabies.
(1967 Code §3-9)
507.04 FEE; EXPIRATION DATE.
   The fees for obtaining dog licenses under the provisions of this article
shall be three dollars ($3.00) for each male or female dog. Such licenses shall
expire July 1 following the date of issue. The license fee mentioned above
shall not apply to dogs in a licensed kennel or veterinary hospital. (Ord. 81-
28. Passed 7-20-81.)
507.05 UNLAWFUL ATTACHING OR REMOVAL OF LICENSE TAG.
   No person shall attach a license tag to any dog to which it was not issued,
or remove a license tag from the collar of any dog without the consent of its
owner.
(1967 Code §3-11)
507.06 LICENSE EXEMPTIONS.
   All seeing eye dogs are exempted from the licensing provisions of this
article.
(1967 Code §3-12)
507.07 DOG POUND; HUMANE OFFICER.
   The Mayor may cause a dog pound to be established and maintained and employ
a person to have charge of such pound, which person is hereby designated as the
Humane Officer. The Humane Officer shall have authority to make reasonable
rules and regulations relating to the operation and maintenance of the pound.
Such rules and regulations are subject to such modifications as Council may
desire to make from time to time.
(1967 Code §3-15)
507.08 RECORD AND DISPOSITION OF FUNDS RECEIVED.
   All moneys received by the Humane Officer under this article shall be
recorded in a bound book. All license fees shall be turned over weekly to the
City Clerk, who shall issue a receipt to the Humane Officer for the same. Such
funds shall be deposited in the General Fund of the City, and all other money
received by the Humane Officer shall be used by the City for operating and
maintenance expenses. (1967 Code §3-16)
507.09 EQUIPMENT.
   The City Clerk, subject to the approval of Council, shall acquire such
equipment as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this article. (1967
Code §3-17)
507.10 INTERFERING WITH HUMANE OFFICER; MALICIOUS ASSAULT; UNLAWFUL ASSAULT;
PENALTIES.
   (a)   Any person who hinders, molests, or interferes with the Humane Officer
or any other person authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this
article is guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
fined two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), may be confined in jail for not less
than thirty days or both fined and confined .
   (b)   Any person who maliciously shoots, stabs, cuts or wounds or by any
means causes bodily injury with intent to maim, disfigure, disable or kill a
Humane Officer acting in his or her official capacity and the person committing
the malicious assault knows or has reason to know that the victim is a Humane
Officer acting in his or her official capacity, is guilty of a felony and shall
be charged as defined in West Virginia Code 61-2-10b.
   (c)   Any person who unlawfully but not maliciously shoots, stabs, cuts or
wounds or by any means causes a Humane Officer acting in his or her official
capacity, bodily injury with intent to maim, disfigure, disable or kill him or
her and the person committing the unlawful assault knows or has reason to know
that the victim is a Humane Officer acting in his or her official capacity, is
guilty of a felony and shall be charged as defined in West Virginia Code 61-2-
10b.
   (d)   Any person who unlawfully, knowingly and intentionally makes physical
contact of an insulting or provoking nature with a Humane Officer in his or her
official capacity, or unlawfully and intentionally causes physical harm to a
Humane Officer acting in such capacity, is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be
charged as defined in West Virginia Code 61-2-10b. If any person commits a
second such offense, he or she is guilty of a felony and shall be charged as
defined in West Virginia Code 61-2-10b. Any person who commits a third
violation of this subsection is guilty of a felony and shall be charged as
defined in West Virginia Code 61-2-10b.
   (e)   Any person who unlawfully attempts to commit a violent injury to the
person of a Humane Officer acting in his or her official capacity, or
unlawfully commits an act which places a Humane Officer acting in his or her
official capacity in reasonable apprehension of immediately receiving a violent
injury, is guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
fined five hundred dollars ($500.00), and may be confined in jail for not less
than thirty days, or both fined and confined.
(Ord. 2003-25. Passed 11-3-03.)
507.11 ENTICING; SEIZING OR MOLESTING; IMPOUNDING OR KILLING.
   Except for persons duly authorized by this article, no person shall entice
any properly licensed dog into any enclosure for the purpose of taking off his
collar or tag, or, for such purpose, decoy or entice any dog out of the
enclosure or house of its owner or possessor, or seize or molest any dog which
is held or led by any person, or bring any dog into the City for the purpose of
impounding and killing the same. (1967 Code §3-19)
507.12 INDUCING TO FIGHT; FRIGHTENING PERSONS.
   No person shall entice, induce, urge or cause any dog to engage in or
prolong a fight in the City, and no person shall induce or cause any dog to run
after, bark at, frighten or bite any person or animal lawfully passing along or
standing in or on any street or highway in the City.
(1967 Code §3-20)
507.13 VICIOUS DOGS.
   (a)    Definitions.
      (1)    A "vicious" dog as term is used in this section means:
         A.   Any dog with a propensity, tendency or disposition to attack, to
cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of human beings or domestic
animals; or
         B.   Any dog which attacks a human being or a domestic animal without
provocation.
      (2)    A vicious dog is "unconfined" as the term is used in this section
if such dog is not securely confined indoors or confined in a securely enclosed
and locked pen or structure upon the premises of the person described in
subsection (a)(2)B. hereof. Such pen or structure must have secure sides and a
secure top. If the pen or structure has no bottom secured to the sides, the
sides must be imbedded in the ground no less than two feet. Such pen or
structure MUST be approved by the St. Albans Humane Officer and/or a St. Albans
Police Officer.
         A.   No person owning or harboring or having the care of a vicious dog
shall suffer or permit such animal to go unconfined on the premises of such
person.
         B.   No person owning or harboring or having the care of a vicious dog
shall suffer or permit such animal to go unconfined on the premises of such
person unless such dog is securely leashed and muzzled.
      (3)    "Vicious dog" does not include either of the following:
         A.   A dog that has killed or caused serious injury or has attacked or
injured any person while that person was committing or attempting to commit a
criminal offense;
         B.   A police dog while being used to assist one or more law
enforcement officers in the performance of their duties.
   (b)   Enforcement.
      (1)   For the purpose of enforcing this section, the Humane Officer,
police officer or Mayor may cause a vicious dog or dogs to be impounded in the
custody and care of a licensed veterinarian or the Kanawha County Animal
Shelter, and a citation issued and served on the owner, owners, or caretaker or
provider of any such vicious dog. The citation may be issued and served after
the impounding of said vicious dog or dogs, if the owner, owners or caretaker
or provider is not present or if the owner, owners, or caretaker or provider
cannot be readily ascertained, provided that the citation shall be issued and
served on the vicious dog owner, owners or caretaker or provider as soon after
the vicious dog or dogs have been impounded as possible, and the owner, owners
or caretaker or provider shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard at the
next regularly scheduled session of Municipal Court after service of the
citation on such person. Service of the citation on the dog owner, owners, or
caretaker or provider of any such dog or dogs may be in person, on any person
over the age of sixteen years present at the residence of such person, or by
any other means or method permitted by law. Upon final disposition by the
Municipal Judge, the dog or dogs may be released to the owner, owners, or
caretaker upon proof that all associated costs for the impoundment of the
vicious dog or dogs have been paid in full. Should the owner, owners, or
caretaker fail to pay in full the costs of impoundment, the Municipal Judge may
order the dog or dogs be euthanized at the expense of the owner, owners or
caretaker.
      (2)   If the violation of this section is, or has not been observed by
the Humane Officer, police officer or Mayor, any person observing any violation
of this section may sign a complaint, and cause a citation for violation of
this section to be issued and served in the manner provided above, provided
that any person signing such complaint shall also be notified of a hearing to
be scheduled before the Municipal Court. Failure to appear and testify in
regard to said citation shall be cause for dismissal of the same.
   (c)   Penalties.
      (1)   No person shall own, keep or harbor any vicious dog or dogs as
defined herein. Upon satisfactory proof before the Judge or the Municipal Court
that such dog, or dogs is or are vicious, the Judge shall fine the owner,
keeper or possessor of such dog or dogs five hundred dollars ($500.00) and may
authorize the Humane Officer to cause such dog to be euthanized, or both. (Ord.
2022-09. Passed 10-17-22.)
507.14 NOISY DOGS.
   (a)   No person shall own, maintain, or otherwise, by act or omission, keep
a dog which, by barking, howling, crying or in any other noise-making manner,
disturbs the peace, comfort or quiet of any neighborhood within the City.
   (b)   For purposes of enforcing this section, the Humane Officer, Mayor or
police officer when the Human Officer is not on duty or scheduled to be
working, may cause a dog to be impounded, and a citation issued and served on
the owner, owners, or care takers or providers of any such dog barking,
howling, crying, or in any other noise-making manner disturbing the peace,
comfort or quiet of any neighborhood within the City. A citation may be issued
without impounding the dog if the owner, owners, or care takers or providers of
any such dog are immediately present, or make their presence known, and
immediately take control over such dog and cause the same to be and remain
quiet, such as taking the dog inside where it cannot be heard, and keeping it
inside. The citation may be issued and served after the impounding of said dog,
if the owner, owners or care takers or providers are not present, or make their
presence immediately known to the Humane Officer, Mayor or police officer on
the premises where the dog is present and violating this section, if the
identity of such dog owner, owners or care taker or provider cannot be readily
ascertained, if the dog is running at large, or if such person fails to
immediately take control over such dog and cause the same to be and remain
quiet, such as taking the dog inside where it cannot be heard, and keeping it
inside, provided that the citation shall be issued and served on the dog owner,
owners or care takers or providers as soon after the dog has been impounded as
possible, and the owner, owners, or care takers or providers of any such dog
shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard at the next regularly scheduled
session of Municipal Court after service of the citation on such person.
Service of the citation on the dog owner, owners, or care takers or providers
of any such dog may be in person, on any person over the age of sixteen years
present at the residence of such person, or by any other manner or method
permitted by law, or in accordance with Rule 4 of the Rules of Civil Procedure
adopted and approved by the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
   (c)   If the violation of this section is, or has not been observed by the
Humane Officer, Mayor, or police officer of this City, any person observing any
violation of this section may sign a complaint, and cause a citation for
violation of this section to be issued and served in the manner provided above,
provided that any person signing such complaint shall also be notified of a
hearing to be scheduled before the Municipal Court concerning any citation
issued and served as a result of said complaint, and shall be afforded the same
opportunity to be heard. Failure to appear and testify in regard to said
citation shall be cause for dismissal of the same.
   (d)   Any person adjudged to be guilty of violating this section shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor, and fined in accordance with Section
507.99 of this Code.
(Ord. 2001-03. Passed 3-5-01.)
507.15 MUZZLING DOGS.
   Whenever it appears to the Mayor that there are good reasons for believing
that any dog within the City is rabid, he may issue a proclamation requiring
that all dogs shall, for a period to be defined in the proclamation, wear good,
substantial muzzles, securely put on, so as to prevent them from biting or
snapping, and any dog at large during the period defined by the Mayor without
such muzzle, shall be taken by the Humane Officer and impounded.
(1967 Code §3-23)
507.16 BITES; IMPOUNDING.
   Whoever owns or harbors a dog, whether licensed or unlicenced, which bites
any other person shall forthwith confine and quarantine the dog in the custody
and care of a licensed veterinarian for a period of fourteen days for rabies
observation. If such dog is not confined and quarantined, the Humane Officer or
Police Officer will cause such dog to be placed in the custody and care of a
licensed veterinarian for such purpose at the owner’s expense. In the event it
should be ascertained that the dog has rabies, then the Humane Officer is
authorized to cause such dog to be euthanized at owner’s expense.
   In addition, the Humane Officer shall declare the animal to be a vicious dog
as defined herein, and the owner, owners, or caretaker shall be issued a
citation as outlined in Section
507.13. (Ord. 2005-17. Passed 8-15-05.)
507.17 COOPERATION WITH OTHER GOVERNMENTAL BODIES.
   In carrying out the intent and provisions of this article, the City is
expressly authorized to enter into agreements with other Municipalities and the
County Court for the purchase of necessary equipment and supplies, employment
of necessary personnel, operation and maintenance of a dog pound, and all other
matters relating to the provisions of this article and to share the cost
thereof with other municipalities and the County Court on a joint and mutual
basis. (1967 Code §3-25)
507.18 RUNNING AT LARGE; CONFINEMENT; ON LEASH; IMPOUNDING;
DEFECATION.
   (a)   No dog, whether wearing a license tag or not, shall be permitted to
run at large within the City at any time except on the property owned or
occupied by the owner of such dog. Any dog found running at large in violation
of this section shall be seized by the Humane Officer and forthwith impounded.
   (b)   The owner of a dog or person harboring or keeping a dog shall not
allow such dog to roam at large in the City whether wearing a license tag or
not. The owner of a dog or the person harboring or keeping a dog shall confine
such dog at the owner’s premises or at the premises of such person harboring or
keeping the dog. No person shall take any dog onto the streets or sidewalks of
the City unless the dog shall be on a leash, or under effective control.
(Ord. 78-18. Passed 6-19-78.)
   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly allow a dog or other
animal owned by him or under his control to defecate upon any street, sidewalk
or other public property. In the event that a dog or other animal owned by or
under the control of a person defecates upon any street, sidewalk or other
public property, the person shall immediately remove such defecation. Any
person who knowingly allows a dog or other animal owned by him or under his
control to defecate upon any street, sidewalk or other public property and who
subsequently fails to remove said defecation, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor,
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars
($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   (d)   The owner, owners, caretaker or provider of any dog impounded by the
Humane Officer, police officer or Mayor, shall be responsible for any and all
impounding and reclamation fees, boarding fees and other costs and fees
incurred and/or assessed. No dog shall be released until all of the foregoing
costs have been paid and proof of a valid registration evidencing current
rabies immunization and any other requirements of registration are provided.
(Ord. 2003-25. Passed 11-3-03.)
507.19 WARRANTS.
   A warrant shall issue only upon complaint on oath or affirmation supported
by affidavit sworn to or affirmed by the Humane Officer or police officer
before the Municipal Judge or Mayor, setting forth the facts establishing the
grounds for issuing the warrant. If the judge or Mayor is satisfied that there
is probable cause to believe that grounds therefor exist, he shall issue a
warrant identifying the property and particularly describing the place, or
naming or particularly describing the person, to be searched. The warrant shall
be directed to the Humane Officer or any police officer of the Municipality, or
to any other officer authorized by law to execute search warrants. If shall
state the grounds or probable cause for its issuance and the names of the
persons whose affidavits have been taken in support thereof. It shall command
the officer to search forthwith the person or place named for the property
specified, to seize such property and bring the same before the Judge or Mayor
issuing the warrant. Such warrant may be executed either in the day or night.
(Ord. 2003-25. Passed 11-3-03.)
507.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any section is this article if no specific penalty is
provided shall be fined as follows:
   (a)   For the first offense - $25.00.
   (b)   For the second offense within one year - $50.00.
   (c)   For the third offense within one year - $100.00.
   (d)   For the fourth offense within one year - $500.00.
   The Humane Officer, police officer or an aggrieved individual may cause a
warrant to be issued by the Mayor or Municipal Judge to the dog owner, owners,
caretaker or provider, in violation of this article.
(Ord. 2003-25. Passed 11-3-03.)

505.06
 
508.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   As used in this article, "owner" means the owner, keeper or harborer
of a cat; any person residing or inhabiting any house, apartment, trailer or
dwelling within the City who allows or permits any cat to remain at or about
such premises, shall also be deemed the owner of such cat for the purposes of
this article.
   (b)   As used in this article, "at large" means off the premises of the
owner and not under the control of the owner or a member of his immediate
family, either by leash, cord, chain or other restricting device or mechanism.
(Ord. 93-19. Passed 12-6-93.)
508.02 RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED.
   Any person owning, keeping or harboring a cat which runs at large within the
City shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(Ord. 93-19. Passed 12-6-93.)
508.03 SQUALLING OR CRYING CATS.
   No owner or any other person shall keep or harbor upon or about his premises
any cat which shall, by squalling, crying or in any manner whatsoever disturb
the comfort or quiet of any neighborhood within the City.
(Ord. 93-19. Passed 12-6-93.)
508.04 REGISTRATION; TAGS REQUIRED.
   The owner, keeper or person having in his possession or allowing to remain
on any premises under his control, a cat above the age of six months, shall
annually have such cat assessed by the City and upon the annual showing that
the cat has a current rabies shot, shall pay to the City a two dollar ($2.00)
annual registration fee, per cat, and shall require such cat to wear a valid
registration tag at all times and to do and perform all other duties and
obligations imposed by West Virginia Code, Article 19, as amended, or as may
hereafter be amended.
(Ord. 94-10. Passed 8-1-94.)
508.05 IMPOUNDING AND DISPOSITION.
   The Animal Officer of the City shall seize and impound any cat running at
large within the City.
   If the cat is wearing a valid registration tag or other identification, or
if the owner is known, the Animal Officer shall make a reasonable effort to
return such cat to the owner. Upon returning the cat as aforesaid, the Animal
Officer shall serve upon the owner a citation to appear before the Police Judge
of the City at a time not less than five days from the date of such service;
prior to the time fixed for appearance, the Animal Officer shall deliver to the
Judge a copy of the citation and shall sign a complaint setting forth the
violation.
   If the cat is not returned to the owner pursuant to the provisions of the
preceding paragraph, the Animal Officer shall impound such cat.
   If the owner desires to redeem such cat within five days from the date the
cat was impounded, he may do so by paying to the Kanawha County Animal Shelter
the following costs and fees:
   (a)   Impounding and reclamation fees;
   (b)   Boarding fees;
   (c)   Other fees and costs incurred and/or assessed by the Kanawha County
Animal Shelter.
   No cat shall be released from the Shelter until all of the foregoing costs
have been paid and the cat is wearing a valid registration tag evidencing
proper rabies vaccination and other requirements of registration.
   If the owner of such impounded cat has not redeemed such cat, as provided in
this section, within five days from the date the cat was impounded, such cat
shall be sold at private or public sale, destroyed or otherwise disposed of by
the Kanawha County Animal Shelter, consistent with law.
(Ord. 93-19. Passed 12-6-93.)
508.06 INTERFERING WITH HUMANE OFFICER; MALICIOUS ASSAULT; UNLAWFUL ASSAULT;
PENALTIES.
   (a)   Any person who hinders, molests, or interferes with the Humane Officer
or any other person authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this
article is guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
fined two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), may be confined in jail for not less
than thirty days or both fined and confined.
   (b)   Any person who maliciously shoots, stabs, cuts or wounds or by any
means causes bodily injury with intent to maim, disfigure, disable or kill a
Humane Officer acting in his or her official capacity and the person committing
the malicious assault knows or has reason to know that the victim is a Humane
Officer acting in his or her official capacity, is guilty of a felony and shall
be charged as defined in West Virginia Code 61-12-10b.
   (c)   Any person who unlawfully but not maliciously shoots, stabs, cuts or
wounds or by any means causes a Humane Officer acting in his or her official
capacity, bodily injury with intent to maim, disfigure, disable or kill him or
her and the person committing the unlawful assault knows or has reason to know
that the victim is a Humane Officer acting in his or her official capacity, is
guilty of a felony and shall be charged as defined in West Virginia Code 61-2-
10b.
   (d)   Any person who unlawfully, knowingly and intentionally makes physical
contact of an insulting or provoking nature with a Humane Officer acting in his
or her official capacity, or unlawfully and intentionally causes physical harm
to a Humane Officer acting in such capacity, is guilty of a misdemeanor and
shall be charged as defined in West Virginia Code 61-2-10b. If any person
commits a second such offense, he or she is guilty of a felony and shall be
charged as defined in West Virginia Code 61-2-10b. Any person who commits a
third violation of this subsection is guilty of a felony and shall be charged
as defined in West Virginia Code 61-2-10b.
   (e)   Any person who unlawfully attempts to commit a violent injury to the
person of a Humane Officer acting in his or her official capacity, or
unlawfully commits an act which places a Humane Officer acting in his or her
official capacity in reasonable apprehension of immediately receiving a violent
injury, is guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
fined five hundred dollars ($500.00), and may be confined in jail for not less
than thirty days, or both fined and confined.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 11-3-03.)
508.07 WARRANTS.
   A warrant shall issue only upon complaint on oath or affirmation supported
by affidavit sworn to or affirmed by the Humane Officer or police officer
before the Municipal Judge or Mayor, setting forth the facts establishing the
grounds for issuing the warrant. If the Judge or Mayor is satisfied that there
is probable cause to believe that grounds therefor exist, he shall issue a
warrant identifying the property and particularly describing the place, or

(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 11-3-03.)
508.08 DEFECATION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly allow a cat or other animal
owned by him or under his control to defecate upon any street, sidewalk or
other public property. In the event that a cat or other animal owned by or
under the control of a person defecates upon any street, sidewalk or other
public property, the person shall immediately remove such defecation. Any

($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 11-3-03.)

   (c)   For the third offense within one year - $100.00.

03.)

509.01 DISTURBING THE PEACE.
   No person shall fight or quarrel or use loud and boisterous, profane or
obscene language or sing or halloo or make any unnecessary noise, such as shall
amount to a disturbance of the peace on any avenue, street, alley or in any
place within the City.
(1967 Code §14-8)
509.02 DISORDERLY ASSEMBLY.
   No person or persons shall congregate and assemble in or upon any street, or
in or around any public building or enclosure, or any park or reservation or at
the entrance or exit of any private building or enclosure so as to impede the
safe, free untrammeled passage of any other persons using or having occasion to
use such street or portions thereof or such public or private buildings,
enclosures, parks or reservations and there engage in fighting, quarreling or
threatening violence to persons or property of others and otherwise engage in
acts by conduct or words, calculated to and which in the normal course of
events would create, cause or lead to a breach of the peace and tranquility of
the inhabitants of the City.
(1967 Code §14-26)
509.03 NOISE PRODUCING DEVICES.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
509.03 was repealed by Ordinance 2000-21, passed December 4, 2000.)
509.04 UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLAGES.
   No person or persons shall assemble on the streets of the City or on the
sidewalks within the City so as to obstruct the passage of any person, and it
shall be the duty of any police officer to order such persons so obstructing to
disperse. No person shall fail to comply with any such order of a police
officer.
(1967 Code §14-34)
509.05 LOITERING ON SCHOOL PROPERTY.
   No person, not a student in regular attendance, shall loiter in or about any
school, school building or school grounds in violation of any posted rules or
regulations governing the use of any such school without written permission
from the principal.
(WVaC 61-6-14a; Ord. 77-21. Passed 11-7-77.)

   (EDITOR’S NOTE: See Section
